content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail shows a section of tissue dominated by a large, multinodular, and irregularly shaped basophilic mass, consistent with a primary tumor. This tumor appears to be infiltrating into the surrounding pink, lobulated adipose tissue. There are no clearly distinct, encapsulated lymph nodes visible; the main feature is the extensive primary tumor.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this area because it is a representative section of the tumor mass. The green box is placed over a region that displays the classic architectural features of the tumor, including both solid-looking areas and regions with apparent glandular spaces. This allows for a detailed assessment of the tumor's morphology, its grade, and the presence of features like necrosis, which are crucial for diagnosis and prognosis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I see an invasive adenocarcinoma. The tumor is composed of irregular, back-to-back, and cribriform glands. The malignant epithelial cells show significant nuclear atypia, including hyperchromasia, irregular nuclear contours, and prominent nucleoli. A key finding is the presence of extensive central eosinophilic material within the glands, which is characteristic of 'dirty necrosis'. The surrounding stroma is desmoplastic, indicating a host reaction to the invasion. My impression is that of a moderately differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma, with features typical for a colorectal primary.
